response.content:
Thank you Monogeo,

Although it’s not required any prior knowledge in MongoDB or Node-Express, I tried to make very clear in the course description that this course is for intermediate students in React.

Knowledge of basic concepts in React such as: react life cycle methods (componentDidMount) or “state” and “props” are required and I purposely not explain them for not interrupting the flow and so disappoint the most of students who expect to learn more complex concepts and patterns.

Anyway, I encourage anyone to write me a direct message or open an Q&A with any question regardless the level of complexity and I will be more than happy to help you out digging on basic concept too.

Should you still have any queries or doubts, please, open a Q&A or drop me a message at any time.

Best regards
Marco

response.content:
Thank you Khaled, for your feedback!

You can find many similar complains in other courses on Udemy made by native language instructors too and I was actually surprise no one yet complained about after so many enrolments.

Unfortunately, this is a difficult problem to overcome for any instructor once our courses are all available to a global audience.

I'm living abroad since more than 10 years now and I’ve been working face to face and virtually with people from almost every part of the world and I can tell you that there are some specific accents which I still have an issue to grasp.

To be honest, I don’t think that adding subtitles is a good solution for a wider audience, some people might complain that subtitles makes difficult to read the code. I would rather use the effort to add more useful contents to the course.

But should you find too difficult to understand me, please, accept my apologies in advance and request a refund for which everyone enrolling this course is entitle to within 30 days.

Best Regards
Marco

response.content:
Thank you Michael for your feedback!

Just a comment about the concetps.

It is true that you will not find concepts about React which a non-absolute beginner in React is supposed to know, but the course is full of concepts related the full stack.

Maybe you didn’t have the impression of confronting yourself with many concepts because, as you said, the course has been carefully designed to go straight to the point making the concepts so easy to absorb that you didn’t even realized.

Indeed, in the course you find:
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” Redux
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” React-router
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” NoSql databases
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” API 
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” a reverse proxy 
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” user sessions
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” server-side rendering 
- “what is”, “why you need” and “how it works” Universal rendering
 
All the above are concepts, I would say that this course, it is packed with concepts.

Please, let me know if is there any concept you were expecting to be in this course which you didn’t find and maybe I didn’t think to include.

The "secret" of this course is to polish all complex concepts above by filtering out all the informations related to the concept which are unnecessary/irrelevant to know and to focus the audience on what is relevant and necessary to enable you to easily expand it further if you need/want.

Ultimately, the goal of this course or I would say, any course, it’s to put you on a position from where you can understand and use these concepts appropriately. 
If me, as an instructor, get you to this point, you can easily expand what you have learnt to any directions and use the concepts independently for your own projects and straight after the course.

Thank you once again!
Cheers
Marco

results.content:
I haven't yet been able to complete this project. I haven't given up yet, but I have been through the entire class, and this is what I come away with. This is only my opinion.

The e-book is supposed to be a "follow-along" endeavor. However, it is not made clear how to use it. Its examples conflict at many points with either the lecture, the source code, or both. 

And although the instructor answered my initial two queries immediately, when I asked him for some clarification on this specific issue, he never answered back. I feel abandoned. I had high hopes for this class. I invested a lot of time that I now feel was wasted.

I really enjoyed the instructor and the lectures. I did learn a lot. There just wasn't enough information (or maybe I should say that the information wasn't clear enough) for me to put everything into a viable project.

results.content:
I have just completed the course in full.

I thoroughly enjoyed it and learned a lot and feel well on my way to creating my first non-trivial MERN app.

I have some experience with MEAN but decided to pick up React instead after looking into it since it felt more intuitive to me than Angular. 

This course was great in that it focuses on setting up front end React/Redux stuff first and describing how to connect the two in just enough detail to know how to use it but not so much you get bored knowing unnecessary ins and outs of each function. 

After that, you will create a backend using Node/Express with nice touch of using reverseProxy which helps separate your server logic among other benefits. 

Then comes Mongo and basic CRUD functions we all know and love and connecting to Redux to save data from user, manipulate, and show to user. Sessions are also implemented using Mongo and a couple helper modules which is interesting and will definitely be useful when creating a real app for creating persistent components. 

For me, this is really all i needed. Now I have an excellent MERN stack template I can reuse and begin creating my own apps understanding how each part fits with the other.

The last section is about how to make your app universal. To be honest, I breezed thru this section and so I can't blame Marco too much but it did seem a bit quick without too much explanation for those unfamiliar with the process. 

Finishes off with deployment and after all that you'll be proficient in MERN stack (and maybe Universal JS).

Thanks to Marco and will look for courses in the future.

Oh yeah, one big thing that separates this course from others is that the instructor went thru the trouble of creating an e-book companion with ALL the code from lectures. This is so helpful and really helps with catching errors. On numerous occasions, I would have never figured it out without referencing the ebook code. Really nifty and appreciated. Hope to see implemented in more Udemy courses.

results.content: Awesome course!  Much less academic than most of the courses I've seen on here and more like job shadowing a web developer demonstrating the breadth of his modern full stack techniques and patterns.  Due to the density of concepts covered through the development of the app (as well as my lack of experience, particularly with back end), I sometimes found myself struggling to keep track of all the components and features that were being layered on with each successive video.  Fortunately, there is a companion eBook to the course that contains all the code covered in the videos, with all the changes introduced throughout the videos highlighted very clearly in yellow so that you can pause the videos and take your time to study the new code before proceeding.

results.content:
Overall this was a good course.

The instructor is very knowledgeable, the course is well structured, concepts are explained in depth and the code being written in the videos is almost always accompanied by explanatory remarks. 

At times, however, the videos are a little coarse. For example: 
- The instructor makes a typo. Instead of revising the video itself, he adds warning text over the section with the typo and leaves the resulting error and his corrections in the video. While correcting the error, he makes a code change or executes a command in the terminal rather quickly. 
- The instructor copy/pastes code from one file to another. Instead of changing the enclosed variable names, he leaves them as is (i.e. names referring to books inside code for the cart) and moves on to the next task.
Moments like these sometimes make it difficult to be sure of which file is being edited, often creating the need to rewatch a section of video more than once when this occurs. 

There are also a few things that could be done differently with the content. React Router 4 is relegated to an appendix. Authentication is not covered. Some common best practices for libraries like React (i.e. PropTypes, SFCs) and Redux (i.e. configureStore, including middleware based on the environment) are not included.

On the whole, I would recommend this course, especially if you're newer to React + Redux or you'd like to use them in conjunction with a NoSQL API. You'll build a functional full-stack application from start-to-finish. On the way, you'll learn how the pieces work and why they're put together the way they are. You'll also learn how to deploy it to two major platforms: both Heroku and AWS.

After you type something in, you have the tendency of quickly scrolling to the next section of code causing your students to throw errors that are otherwise avoidable. You need to linger a few seconds before switching to a new file or block of code or students will keep throwing errors because they missed the last thing you typed.

This happened frequently with me when you were typing the export default functions for mapStateToProps, mapDispatchToProps at the bottom of your pages js files. 

Thank you and I hope this helps.

Overall very good. Probably not for beginner level students, but easy to understand if you're familiar with Javascript. The instruction is pretty good with enough explanation into why things are done a certain way. However, the video moves a little too quickly through some parts where a lot of typing has happened causing me to do a lot of pausing and restarting, which is my only real complaint.

response.content:
Thank you so much, Dakota!

Well spotted!  I'm going to amend the react-router installation right now!

With regards the speed, I agree that a couple of videos are a little too fast and I have in plan to slow them down just a little bit. But there is a very specific reason why I decided to increase the typing speed in some videos.

This course is designed to teach “concepts” and “patterns” behind the full-stack.
I believe that when learning a programming language it’s crucial to understand the concepts and patterns before syntax. 
Now… in order to achieve so, I have to provide the audience with quick view of the patterns prior writing any code.

You might have noticed that in some cases I show the patterns using animated slides, but in some other cases the slides don’t really make sense and I have to show the pattern directly from the code and as quickly as possible in order to maintain the audience attention  to the pattern rather than to the code.
Of course, this has the drawback for which you might end up in the need to watch some videos twice in order to complete your code, but honestly, I believe that it's worth the effort for the student to do.

Thank you once again for your feedback
Best Regards!

results.content: I usually try to keep my critiques positive. I took this course to look into isomorphic rendering and deploying to aws. I already am a seasoned react dev, and saw some issues and redundancies in this project. i.e the use of the proxy server when both the client and backend can be on the same server. If it's just an example I can understand that, but you should make that clear. I also think you should define the dependences and their properties you use so it makes sense to the beginning users

response.content:
Thank you Isaac,

You are confusing the isomorphic concept with full server side rendering one. In an isomorphic app the client and the backend are not in the same server, only the first request is rendered by the server all the subsequent requests are rendered by the client as soon as the js code (bundle.js) is available in the client.

I see you skipped all the introduction to Universal implementation and jumped directly to the lectures where we transform the app from fully client to isomorphic. I suggest you to watch the introduction to Universal.

Anyway, FYI the use of a proxy server would be still valid even on a server side rendered application. 

Cheers
Marco

results.content:
I thought this was a fantastic course and really appreciated Marco as an instructor. I absolutely loved the supplemental PDF, which turned out to be the perfect debugging tool. Marco's explanations were clear and detailed; however, there were times when he wrote code without explanation and I wasn't totally sure what was going on. The pace was also quite brisk and I typically had to stop and/or rewind a video several times to review or keep up with writing the code. However, in his defense, I think that is often the case with online learning and one should expect to do it regardless. 

I would recommend this course if you've already had some exposure to React and are looking for supplemental tutorials. However, for total newbies, you might find yourself struggling a bit. In either case, Marco definitely knows what he's doing. 

THANK YOU for a great course!

results.content:
There are too many inconsistent, confusion, error prone, outdated, glitches, over-engineering and etc. 

Especially with lack with information or warning on updated changes. For example, every lesson I went though, I end up got lost, become confused. Having to go back and forth replaying videos several time and/or digging through PDF just because one syntax have changed in future date without much clear explanation and this is so exasperating!  Bottom line, I've spend almost 70% of time in troubleshooting with code rather than enjoy learning it as success. 

Another thing, based on my experiences. I must say the architecture and logical view is rather messy!  In theory, React/Redux as client side render shouldn't merge with express as (server side render). It should run parallel instead to avoid hard-to-debug, complex update and etc in the future.  Especially for one who uses boilerplate (eg. create-react-app, parcel, and etc)

However, I do believe instructor did great job, he probably did his best with everything. Did a full contribution on answering a lot of questions. This would have become a lot better if instructor spend more time making sure lesson are clear for everyone to follow be sure student acknowledge clear on update changes.

Thanks the eBook I could sort my self out in a couple of occasions I made typing mistakes.
I love shopping cart app I have build during the course. I think it was a great idea to use it for explaining the entire stack in one course and planning to use the same architecture in my next project.
If you are an absolute beginner, it is better you learn the foundation of React first, the course starts from explaining Redux assuming you have the bases in React already.

results.content: This is one of the best courses on Udemy for this type of instruction particularly for developers who need to get up to speed quickly. Redux can be difficult to grasp, but there is enough material here to achieve that. Everything in one place, as it says on the tin 'Full Stack' enabling me to focus on areas not clear by researching for more info. The accompanying PDF is very good as a learning aid explaining each step clearly. The tutor has a slight accent so for that I've awarded 4.5 stars instead of five, but nobody's perfect.

results.content:
I highly recommend this course for anyone with basic front-end development skills that wants to learn React and Redux in a full-stack application!

I'm primarily a back-end developer but have dabbled on the front-end side before. But, I have never felt confident building a full scale front-end application. This course makes it simpler and more straightforward than it has ever felt for me before. You will have the foundation of a serious application up and running before you know it!

Also, in my experience, Marco has been a very helpful and responsive instructor. He has mentioned his plans to add some detail to the course in a few key areas and it sounds like it will be getting even better in the future!

response.content:
Thank you Joseph, much appreciated!

Again, as told you in our chat, don't hesitate to drop me a message should you have any queries! 
I always love to hear from people in this course and talk about future plans, answer to questions or exchange views and opinions related to software development.

And finally, I confirm, what you suggested are very interesting topics and they will be the first things I will included in  coming additions to the course .

Best Regards
Marco

The reality is that it's impossible to get a speed right for a wide audience, some would feel it too slow others will fell too fast.

Cheers
Marco

results.content: While there are some good points in this course, e.g. excellent diagrams and taking a simple Redux application and integrating it with React, there are simply way too many errors, many highlighted by overlays from the author, that detract from the learning experience. This disrupts the flow and is quite frustrating to follow along. For example, a short video of a few minutes can last 30 to 40 minutes with the effort needed, constantly replaying sections. Better planning, more retakes when things go wrong and filling of long periods of silence would improve this course.
